4.81.text:
Several people have mailed me recently, sharing
that they're questioning their own religious beliefs.

8.91.text:
Reading their different stories, i'm prompted to share
my own transition to atheism with them —

15.26.text:
taking into account both the emotional and
the cognitive components of that switch.

20.16.text:
So here are two videos, each addressing
one of those aspects

23.54.text:
and using psychological models as frameworks
to contextualise the psychological events involved.

29.18.text:
Sometimes we must face tremendous pain.
The pain of not knowing, of aloneness, of finality.

38.02.text: When we run from that pain, it looms ever larger.

40.96.text: And, fighting fear with fear, we doom ourselves to war.

44.32.text: But when we embrace that pain, it fades to nothing.

46.98.text: And we can move forward, unafraid and curious.

56.12.text:
In this video I'm using a seven-stage model
of psychological transition,

59.85.text:
put forward by Sugarman in her book
Life Span Development,

62.89.text:
to explore the emotional side of my transition
from christian to atheist.

66.39.text:
But first a word about an event that marked
the beginning of my transition to atheism.

70.22.text:
I was in a religious education class at my
non-religious school.

73.37.text:
We'd just swapped teachers.
The first teacher was very religious.

76.53.text:
He was later discovered taking pictures of
some school boys naked round his house,

79.87.text: but let's don't dwell on that shall we.

81.98.text:
His replacement was a cool customer,
I'd say almost military in his demeanour

85.81.text: — and indeed in his safari jackets.

87.62.text:
We had a few template, generic lessons,
nothing mind-blowing

90.51.text: — just learning words like talmud and brahmin.

92.82.text:
Then a lesson where the teacher — let's
call him Mr Elliot; well that was his name —

97.23.text:
showed a science video, which contradicted
bits of the Bible, particularly Genesis.

101.36.text:
For homework, he asked us to write an essay
about our thoughts.

104.34.text:
I went home and wrote the most pompous little
piece of dogma you could imagine.

108.32.text:
No arguments against the video. 
Just dismissing it out of hand.

111.23.text:
And finishing off proudly with: 'I am a christian.
My views will never change!'

117.11.text: Well. Mr Elliot marked it. I got it back.

119.73.text:
And saw he'd commented:
'Yes, you've written what your beliefs are.

122.95.text: 'But are you able to say why you believe them?"

127.51.text: And I wanted him wiped from the face of the planet.

130.72.text:
I think this would be a good point to introduce
the model of psychological transition.

134.32.text: We start with stage one: immobilisation.

137.52.text:
When I first read Mr Elliot's comment,
I just felt total disorientation.

141.88.text:
To me, age 12, god in the christian form I'd
been indoctrinated with, was just reality.

146.59.text:
I'd never questioned it. Now, for the first
time, I was being asked for my reasons.

151.08.text:
I didn't have a clue. All I came up with in
my head was "It's true because it just is!"

157.16.text: And even I recognised how lame that sounded.

160.01.text:
I felt exposed.
I felt caught out, made a fool of.

163.47.text:
Not by the people who'd indoctrinated me 
— no, by Mr Elliot.

167.16.text:
Within days, I developed such a hatred and
detestation for Mr Elliot it was untrue.

173.21.text:
I'd watch him stand there in the background
during assemblies

175.99.text:
and find myself mentally seething, 'Who the Hell
do you think you are??'

180.84.text: I was convinced he was laughing at me,

183.14.text:
sneering at me and my beliefs —  which,
I should say, he never did.

186.18.text: That was total projection on my part.

188.04.text:
But eventually I moved into minimisation,
alleviating some of my stress with a bit of rationalising.

193.80.text:
I rationalised that — all the adults I knew
were christian so christianity was bound to be correct.

198.26.text:
I was comforted by the idea I was part of
the majority.

201.24.text:
It's funny, that was probably the last time
I ever felt part of a majority.

204.48.text:
Anyway I told myself I'd simply
get the answers from them.

209.00.text:
I discovered my fellow christians couldn't
come up with anything better than I had.

212.72.text: Which threw me back to stage one.

214.14.text: And I hovered round these stages for some time.

216.62.text:
Well, that's what happens, you move forward,
you slip back.

219.09.text:
I did everything I could think of to try and
find ways to back up my beliefs.

223.21.text:
Reading the bible was one
of my more counter-productive strategies,

225.77.text:
because it only opened up a whole world of
new contradictions I'd not even thought of.

229.89.text:
Eventually, feeling quite drained,
I slumped into stage three.

233.66.text:
I began to recognise that the situation
probably wasn't going to be rescued.

238.18.text:
Outwardly I was living the same life,
going to church.

241.38.text:
I guess still wanting to hang on to it.
But it all felt totally hollow.

247.38.text: Gradually I slipped into stage four.

249.67.text:
I finally acknowledged there was no substantial
foundation for the beliefs I'd been indoctrinated with.

254.44.text:
I felt I'd been made to say and do the most
ridiculous things in the name of that belief.

259.09.text:
I'd been made to experience the most horrendous
fantasies of eternal torture;

262.89.text:
the most horrendous emotions of guilt, fear
and shame over absolutely nothing.

268.41.text:
The scale of it was very hard to accept.
But finally I had accepted it.

272.55.text:
I began to look around at different belief systems
that might fill the emptiness left behind.

276.68.text:
I looked at different religions, at the occult.
But they all had the same problems.

281.59.text:
I was in limbo.
With a sense of no direction or identity.

284.59.text: And I began to question what 'identity' actually meant.

287.99.text:
I started considering my options,
testing new behaviours.

291.61.text:
First off, announcing at age 14 that I didn't
believe in god and was leaving the church.

296.75.text:
Which immediately sparked a welter of scorn,
contempt, threats, guilt trips, all manner of judgements.

303.98.text:
So next I had to develop new strategies to
cope with that bullying.

307.59.text:
I think for a while I felt so alienated I
just blanked it out.

311.61.text: I didn't recognise these people anymore.

313.94.text: But, as it continued, I began to answer back

316.26.text:
and pull apart the comments
and arguments that were coming my way.

320.15.text:
I knew I was doing nothing wrong in thinking
for myself,

322.94.text:
and actually I just wasn't going to take anymore
punishment for it.

326.22.text:
Christian teachers at school who I'd previously
been friendly with

328.84.text: began to exert their own quasi-parental disapproval.

332.04.text: So, socially, I learned to cut them absolutely dead.

337.48.text: Shutting people out like that was quite isolating.

340.17.text: But if it was a choice between isolation,

342.16.text: or being with people who didn't want me to think,

345.76.text:
One of life's rules: people who don't want
you to think are never your friend.

350.48.text:
Anyway this part of the transition became
substantially about building boundaries.

354.02.text: I'd had very few if any boundaries up to that point.

357.01.text:
Which is probably why so many people felt
so relaxed about walking all over me.

360.51.text:
They never felt they were stepping over the
line because there was no line.

363.83.text:
But now I was drawing that line
— and sticking to it hard.

366.87.text:
And gradually relationships shifted back,
albeit grudgingly, into some semblance of respect.

373.14.text: I'd been handed the meaning of my life as a child.

375.72.text: I now had to find my own meaning.

377.60.text:
But I quickly discovered that life without religion
wasn't the barren land I'd been told it would be.

382.34.text: I found meaning in searching out the truth of things;

385.14.text:
in scientific enquiry; in argument against poor logic
and reasoning, particularly supernatural dogmas.

390.43.text: I found meaning in psychological exploration;

393.25.text: in addressing the distortions that are sometimes forced on us in life, and finding ways to counteract them.

400.05.text:
I was doing things now not because I'd been
instructed or coerced

403.16.text:
but because I'd considered the underlying
principles on a human level.

407.55.text:
Whatever old meaning I'd lost was more than
replaced by the new meaning I found.

413.64.text:
I was at ease with myself. The issues that came up
during the transition no longer dominated my life

420.82.text: It'll be plain, to those who've listened,

423.05.text: that my transition to atheism wasn't some empty rebellion or a descent into self-indulgent immorality.

429.80.text:
It wasn't someone coming along and corrupting
my young brain with blasphemous ideas.

434.44.text:
It was a child actively struggling to hold
onto his religious illusions,

438.36.text:
but eventually acknowledging that there was
absolutely no foundation,

442.44.text: to believe what he'd been told.

444.17.text:
I've had many great teachers in my life,
teachers I've laughed and joked around with,

448.03.text:
teachers I've confided in,
teachers I've had crushes on.

451.06.text: I never had much to do with Mr Elliot.

453.86.text: But I'll always be grateful to him for challenging me,

456.70.text: with that simple, and actually very respectful comment,

460.18.text: considering the tumescence of my essay's pomposity.

464.14.text:
I think of that comment as the surgical knife
in the caesarean section of my intellectual life.

470.24.text: Some blood and guts along the way, birth pains, sure.

473.32.text:
But finally freedom from the confinement
that felt so snug and protective,

478.37.text:
that I didn't realise how utterly immobilising
and stultifying it actually was.

483.01.text:
To anyone watching this, who finds themself
in any of the stages of transition described here,

489.54.text:
You're on your own journey —  it won't
be the same as mine —

492.03.text: but maybe there'll be some parallels.

494.14.text: Now there will undoubtedly be some who see this video

497.33.text: and try to distort the personal story I've shared

499.89.text:
into a fantasy more consistent with the prejudices
they hold against atheists.

504.33.text:
And in the accompanying video — 'atheism
as congruence' —

507.48.text:
I'll explore how that kind of distortion can
come about.
